instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2914: What is 820-2914? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: no green light ppdcin is present and pp5v1  on vdd,vddp of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is present but no voltage going to system on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. not at all familiar as to how <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> works exactly but getting less than 1 volt on pin 25,24 and 23 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> which seems to be what creates <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. what could be the issue guys?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> voltage? Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> in Ohms (with the power disconnected of course)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: ac in voltage is 3.9 and 6mohms and dropping on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
6miliOhms? You have a short to ground

Look for anything that looks messed up and/or getting hot. You might need to inject voltage to see what gets hot though, not sure if <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> will try to keep working when its output is shorted.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Green light should the first thing to be addressed. Is PP3V42 present and is ACOK present?
